An **ogre**, O, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a large, [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") and [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") that is the most basic form of [ogre](/wiki/Ogre_\(monster_class\) "Ogre (monster class)"). An ogre has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), can be seen via infravision and will seek out [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold"), [gems](/wiki/Gem "Gem"), weapons and armor to pick up.

An ogre has a single weapon attack.

[ ]

## Contents

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

## Generation

Randomly generated ogres may be created peaceful towards chaotic characters, and can generate in small [groups](/wiki/Group "Group") of two to four. An ogre can grow up into an [ogre lord](/wiki/Ogre_lord "Ogre lord").

The ogre is the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster for [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), and makes up 96⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Barbarian quest](/wiki/Barbarian_quest "Barbarian quest"). Several ogres are also generated on level creation for each floor of the quest: eleven on the home level, seven on the upper filler level, seventeen on the locate level, seven on the lower filler level(s), and sixteen on the goal level. Ogres may also appear among the random O that are part of the first quest monster class for the Barbarian quest, and make up 24⁄175 of monsters that are randomly generated there.

Ogres are [generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") [some gold](/wiki/Gold_lover "Gold lover") and either a [club](/wiki/Club "Club") (11⁄12 chance) or a [battle-axe](/wiki/Battle-axe "Battle-axe") (1⁄12 chance), and can generate with [offensive](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item"), [defensive](/wiki/Defensive_item "Defensive item") and [miscellaneous items](/wiki/Miscellaneous_item "Miscellaneous item").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

Ogres are quite strong, but generally slow and can easily be picked off from a distance, especially with [projectile](/wiki/Projectile "Projectile") weapons. Characters without the AC or weaponry to try and best an ogre in melee combat may prefer projectiles, though be mindful that ogres can often generate with wands. Wands themselves are a good option to use against ogres, since they lack any [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)").

Barbarians on their quest will want to be particularly mindful of the potential for wands - the flipside of this is that ogres make a good source of loot if they can be dispatched reliably and quickly. Ogre [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") are also a decently good source of nutrition for players and any carnivorous [pets](/wiki/Pets "Pets").

## History

The ogre is introduced in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

From [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0") to [NetHack 3.2.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.3 "NetHack 3.2.3"), ogres are the second quest monster for the defunct Elf role, making up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Elf quest](/wiki/Elf_quest "Elf quest"), and each level of the quest below the home level also generated some ogres at level creation: one on the upper filler level, four on the locate level, two in the lower filler level(s), and eight on the goal level. Ogres can also appear among the random O that are part of the second quest monster class and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Ogre](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ogre "wikipedia:Ogre")***

An ogre (feminine: ogress) is a legendary monster depicted as a large, hideous humanoid being that eats ordinary humans, especially infants and children. Ogres frequently feature in mythology, folklore, literature, and fiction throughout the world, and are most often associated with fairy tales and legend. Ogres are also sometimes depicted with disproportionately large heads, abundant hair, unusually-colored skin, a voracious appetite, and a strong body. Tales featuring well-known ogres include "[Puss in Boots](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puss_in_Boots "wikipedia:Puss in Boots")" and "[Hop-o'-My-Thumb](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hop-o%27-My-Thumb "wikipedia:Hop-o'-My-Thumb")".

Ogres are closely linked with giants and human cannibals in mythology; giants in both folklore and fiction are often given ogrish traits (e.g. the giants in "Jack and the Beanstalk" and "Jack the Giant Killer", the Giant Despair in The Pilgrim's Progress, and the Jötunn of Norse mythology), while ogres may be given giant-like traits. Ogres also appear in the *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* role-playing game as large, powerful humanoids with slightly below average intelligence, and have occasionally featured as playable characters.

The ogres of *NetHack* derive their stats from the 1st Edition *Dungeons & Dragons* Monster Manual, which describes ogres as ugly-tempered, voracious and fond of treasure. They can be found in virtually any terrain, including subterranean areas, and usually serve as mercenaries for orcs, gnolls and/or evil clerics. Ogres also freely dwell near the territories of trolls and some giants, and are sometimes enslaved by demons. Ogres range from "dull blackish-brawn to dead yellow" in color, and wear any sort of skins or furs; they are said to care well for their weapons and armor, despite the slovenly traits associated with them and other folkloric ogres.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), four ogres appear in the halls of [Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold").

In older versions, ogres are the second quest monster for the defunct Gnome role, making up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Gnome quest](/wiki/Gnome_quest "Gnome quest"), and each level of the quest except for the lower filler level(s) also generate some ogres at level creation: ten on the home level, seven on the upper filler level, two on the locate level, and seven on the goal level. Ogres also appear among the random O that are part of the second quest monster class and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

Ogres also appear on the defunct [Hobbit quest](/wiki/Hobbit_quest "Hobbit quest"), where four are generated on the locate level at level creation, and two are generated similarly on the lower filler level(s).

### GruntHack

- *Main article: [Ogre (starting race)](/wiki/Ogre_\(starting_race\) "Ogre (starting race)")*

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), [ogres](/wiki/Ogre_\(starting_race\) "Ogre (starting race)") are a playable race and an eligible race for the various [racial monsters](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") that appear in the dungeon, which includes [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") and [soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") as well as [lords](/wiki/Lord_\(GruntHack\) "Lord (GruntHack)") and [kings](/wiki/King_\(GruntHack\) "King (GruntHack)").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), ogres may appear in the court of a [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room") ruled by an [ogre king](/wiki/Ogre_king "Ogre king").

The [Chaos Temple variant](/wiki/Chaos_Temple_Quest "Chaos Temple Quest") of the [Chaos Quest](/wiki/Chaos_Quest_\(dNetHack\) "Chaos Quest (dNetHack)") generates 2 ogres within the forest area of the Ancient Temple level, and 1⁄10 of the randomly generated monsters on that level will be ogres.

The revamped [Elvish Racial Quest](/wiki/Elvish_Racial_Quest "Elvish Racial Quest") generates three ogres on the locate level of the branch at level creation, as well as generating some in the lower filler level(s).

### SlashTHEM

- *Main article: [Ogre (starting race)](/wiki/Ogre_\(starting_race\) "Ogre (starting race)")*

[SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") also features the ogre as a playable race, formerly called the [ogro](/wiki/Ogro "Ogro").

## Encyclopedia entry

Anyone who has met a gluttonous, nude, angry ogre, will not  
easily forget this encounter -- if he survives it at all.  
Both male and female ogres can easily grow as tall as three  
metres. Build and facial expressions would remind one of a  
Neanderthal. Its small, pointy, keen teeth are striking.  
Since ogres avoid direct sunlight, their ragged, unfurry  
skin is as white as a sheet. They enjoy coating their body  
with lard and usually wear nothing but a loin-cloth. An elf  
would smell its rancid stench at ten metres distance.  
Ogres are solitary creatures: very rarely one may encounter  
a female with two or three young. They are the only real  
carnivores among the humanoids, and its favourite meal is --  
not surprisingly -- human flesh. They sometimes ally with  
orcs or goblins, but only when they anticipate a good meaty  
meal.

\[ The Book of Rules; The Eye of the Master]

In [[SLASH'EM]], four ogres appear in the halls of [[Grund's Stronghold]].

In older versions, ogres are the second quest monster for the defunct Gnome role, making up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Gnome quest]], and each level of the quest except for the lower filler level(s) also generate some ogres at level creation: ten on the home level, seven on the upper filler level, two on the locate level, and seven on the goal level. Ogres also appear among the random {{white|O}} that are part of the second quest monster class and make up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters randomly generated there.

Ogres also appear on the defunct [[Hobbit quest]], where four are generated on the locate level at level creation, and two are generated similarly on the lower filler level(s).

===GruntHack===
{{main|Ogre (starting race)}}
In [[GruntHack]], [[Ogre (starting race)|ogres]] are a playable race and an eligible race for the various [[racial monster]]s that appear in the dungeon, which includes [[shopkeeper]]s and [[soldier]]s as well as [[Lord (GruntHack)|lords]] and [[King (GruntHack)|kings]].

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], ogres may appear in the court of a [[Throne room#dNetHack|throne room]] ruled by an [[ogre king]].

The [[Chaos Temple Quest|Chaos Temple variant]] of the [[Chaos Quest (dNetHack)|Chaos Quest]] generates 2 ogres within the forest area of the Ancient Temple level, and {{frac|10}} of the randomly generated monsters on that level will be ogres.

The revamped [[Elvish Racial Quest]] generates three ogres on the locate level of the branch at level creation, as well as generating some in the lower filler level(s).

===SlashTHEM===
{{main|Ogre (starting race)}}
[[SlashTHEM]] also features the ogre as a playable race, formerly called the [[ogro]].

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|<poem>
Anyone who has met a gluttonous, nude, angry ogre, will not
easily forget this encounter -- if he survives it at all.
Both male and female ogres can easily grow as tall as three
metres.  Build and facial expressions would remind one of a
Neanderthal.  Its small, pointy, keen teeth are striking.
Since ogres avoid direct sunlight, their ragged, unfurry
skin is as white as a sheet.  They enjoy coating their body
with lard and usually wear nothing but a loin-cloth.  An elf
would smell its rancid stench at ten metres distance.
Ogres are solitary creatures:  very rarely one may encounter
a female with two or three young.  They are the only real
carnivores among the humanoids, and its favourite meal is --
not surprisingly -- human flesh.  They sometimes ally with
orcs or goblins, but only when they anticipate a good meaty
meal.
{{right-align|[ The Book of Rules; The Eye of the Master]}}
</poem>}}
